PostgreSQL installation

PostgreSQL is distributed as an Installer package at the following address:
http://www.postgresql.org/download/macosx Another option is to build the server from source. Here's a brief tutorial.

  1. Get the latest PostgreSQL source release (8.2 or later) from http://www.postgresql.org/ftp/source.
  2. Uncompress, configure, make, [sudo] make install. On Mac OS X, Bonjour and OpenSSL are available, so ./configure –-with-bonjour –-with-openssl && make && sudo make install probably gives the expected results.
  3. It's usually a good idea to create a separate user and group for PostgreSQL, but Mac OS X already comes with a database-specific user: for mysql. We'll just use that and hope PostgreSQL doesn't mind.
  4. Make mysql the owner of the PostgreSQL folder, then sudo to mysql:
    sudo chown -R mysql:mysql /usr/local/pgsql
    sudo -u mysql -s
  5. Initialize the PostgreSQL database folder. We'll use en_US.UTF-8 as the default locale:
    LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 /usr/local/pgsql/bin/initdb -D \
    /usr/local/pgsql/data
  6. Launch the PostgreSQL server itself:
    /usr/local/pgsql/bin/pg_ctl -D /usr/local/pgsql/data \
    -l /usr/local/pgsql/data/pg.log start
  7. Create a superuser account for yourself. This way, you don't have to sudo to mysql to create new databases and users.
    /usr/local/pgsql/bin/createuser your-short-user-name
  8. Exit the mysql sudo and create a database. If you create a database with your short user name, psql will connect to it by default.
    exit
    /usr/local/pgsql/bin/createdb your-short-user-name
